Edited July 12, 2014 by MrTheBull
Looks lovely, I assume that you have tested them out with the Real Scale Solarsystem mod?

Looks lovely, I assume that you have tested them out with the Real Scale Solarsystem mod?

No. It's for normal Kerbin size.
I'll be doing an RSS config for this later. Right now, I'm finalizing Soyuz, Proton and MIR. After that's out, I might add Angara and PPTS.

hmm, it seems that the modified block I looks a bit short once it's engines fairings are discarded - unless the Angara block I is supposed to be wider than the Soyuz one . also, i never found anything conclusive on the Angara's ascent profile when using multiple URM's (except that the middle one is supposed to be slightly throttled down) - i don't know if the URM are supposed to be kept together until upper stage ignition or not (with the notable exception of the Baikal Booster )

Edited December 2, 2013 by sgt_flyer

Angara isn't using a modified Soyuz upper stage. This one is fine. That it's called "Block I" is because of Russian way of designating stages. Similarly, one of the boosters on Soyuz is called "Block D", and yet has nothing (well, except fuel type, they're both kerolox) in common with what we usually mean by Block D (the Proton 4th/N1 5th stage).

Also, I don't know about uncrewed launches, but Angara 5P launches with the central URM shut down, and activates it at booster separation (or slightly before, for ullage control). That's how I've been launching it.
Looks great at always. Will try it out today or tomorrow and give feedback.

It seems I'm having quite a lot of trouble launching this in the 4 booster config shown.... Upon liftoff (clamps decouple, engines ignite, or already firing) the boosters just seem to rip themselves, and the rest of the craft apart.... Additionally, with launch clamps to hold the craft steady, the engine bases have a habit of wobbling uncontrollably leading to toppling... Any ideas?

Edit: it seems even the act of igniting the boosters causes the craft to jump... Ripping the attatch nodes apart :-(

Edited December 2, 2013 by Jaybtlr
@dragon01 well, the angara block I and future updated soyuz block I's are going to share the same engine

Struts! More struts!

@dragon01 well, the angara block I and future updated soyuz block I's are going to share the same engine

RD-0124 already flies on the Soyuz. This doesn't mean the rest of the stage is the same. Angara Block I is completely different from Soyuz one, save fore the main engine.

I have started using a gantry strut support hard connecting my center stage to the upper and lower.

It gives an anchor point away from the central core and spreads the thrust off you big main engines through the whole craft instead of smashing flat your decoupler.

Alacrity
I've never had problems with boosters ripping off. They should work, even without struts.

I dont like russian things

And why did you have the need to say that here? Oh, and you do realize that the most realiable rocket ever built is russian? And that the Russian Soyuz is the only way there currently is to get humans to the ISS? Actually, I've gotten curious now. Why don't you like russian things?

Yeah. I know how to do it. Maybe i'll do it.
i have a bug - PPTS crew disappeared after launching((( why?
That usually happens when a stage has broken from the craft and you are currently active on the non crewable piece. Were you still able to control the craft?
Also, aren't you using ECLSS? PPTS doesn't support it, you know. Your crew will die once out of atmo, because the pod carries no oxygen.
Yes, im using Soviet pack with LSS... does it mean if i have LSS folder it influense on every craft either it support LSS or not?
Yes the life support will effect all ships if you arnt using it, just delete the life support folder

Had some problems with the life support mod(ECLSS), when at 35-40 kilometers above Kerbin(only tested in Kerbin's atmosphere), the kerbals simply disappear and the flight results(F3) say that they died, and the Astronaut Complex says that they're missing in action(a smoother way of saying they're dead)
